prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This correlator setup allows us to use a smaller velocuty resolution for stronger than expected emission. If this is not the case we will bin the data to 20 km/s. We have one 1.875GHz spectral window with a frequency resolution of 976kHz for the CO(3-2) line. We have added 3 additional spectraal windows for continuum observation.

The angular resolution is chosen to allow us to resolve the galaxies and map the distribution of the molecular gas. We aim at observing the molecular gas in the nuclear regions of PSQ, so we need to resolve linear sizes of <1kpc, which at the mean redshift of our objects correspond to 0.1".

We estimate the line strength based on a molecular gas mass of 10^9 Msun and a total velocity width of 200 km/s. We also assume a CO-to-H2 conversion higher than for starbursts and lower than for quiescent galaxies (alpha=1.5). The maximum velocity resolution needed to achieve the sciene goals is 20 km/s. For a 5 sigma detection the channel-to-channel noise rms for this source needs to be 1.2mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Post-starburst quasars (PSQ) are postulated to be transitional objects in the metamorphosis of spirals to ellipticals. In current merging scenarios PSQ would be the descendants of (U)LIRGs and the immediate progenitors of post-starburst (K+A) galaxies. However, our study of a sample of 73 bona-fide PSQ from the SDSS revealed that PSQ lack the large intermediate-age metal-rich stellar populations that characterise K+A galaxies. Therefore, either PSQ are not the immediate progenitors of K+As, or they have still not formed the bulk of their young stars. The missing stellar masses of several times 10^9$Msun should be readily observed in molecular gas if PSQ are now forming the stars that will become the bulk of the intermediate-age populations of K+A galaxies. Here we propose to look for CO(3-2) and CO(4-3) emission in a sample of 21 southern PSQ with redshifts z<0.35.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Catholic University of America
